This movie is in public domain category and it is Copyright free.

sources.title: Kansas City Confidential (1952)
sources.description: A down-on-his-luck ex-GI finds himself framed for an armored car robbery. When he's finally released for lack of evidence--after having been beaten up and tortured by the police--he sets out to discover who set him up, and why. The trail leads him into Mexico and a web of hired killers and corrupt cops. Watch on RetroFlix.org:  https://retroflix.org/kansas-city-confidential-1952/

sources.title: Kansas City Confidential (1952) [P&M] 1080p Blu-ray (1.9GB)
sources.description: I scoured the internet for the highest-quality version of this film available online, and this is what I ended up choosing from everything that I found, downloaded via bittorrent. At the time of upload, it looks and sounds much nicer than anything else available on the Archive. For the record, it's one of those situations where the bitrate is lower than a couple of other uploads on the Archive, but that's just do to the sloppy encodes on those other uploads; they don't look or sound anywhere near as good, I think you'll agree. As always, thank you to the original ripper and seeders!

sources.title: Kansas City Confidential
sources.description: Four robbers hold up an armored truck getting away with over a million dollars in cash. Joe Rolfe (John Payne), a down-on-his-luck flower delivery truck driver is accused of being involved and is beaten up by the local police. Released due to lack of evidence, Joe, following the clues to a Mexican resort, decides to look for the men who set him up and get revenge.

sources.title: Kansas City Confidential (1952) [Film Noir]
sources.description:
"Kansas City Confidential" is a 1952 film noir crime film directed by Phil Karlson and starring John Payne. The film was marketed with the tagline "Exploding like a gun in your face!" and released in the United Kingdom as "The Secret Four".

Four robbers hold up an armored truck, getting away with over a million dollars in cash. Joe Rolfe (John Payne), a down-on-his-luck flower delivery truck driver is accused of being involved and is roughly interrogated by local police. Released due to lack of evidence, Joe, following the clues to a Mexican resort, decides to look for the men who set him up both to clear his name and to exact revenge. What he doesn't know is that the heist involves a retired policeman who is also intent on revenge. The plot was inspiration for Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs.

---

Directed by Phil Karlson, produced by Edward Small, screenplay by George Bruce, and Harry Essex, story by Rowland Brown and Harold Greene, starring John Payne
Coleen Gray, Preston Foster, Neville Brand and Lee Van Cleef.

---

Source: "Kansas City Confidential" Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikimedia Foundation, Inc.. 14 August 2012. Web. 31 August 2012. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Confidential.

sources.title: Kansas City Confidential (1952) JOHN PAYNE
sources.description:
Stars: John Payne, Coleen Gray, Lee Van Cleef, Jack Elam 
 Director: Phil Karlson

In this action-packed crime-noir, an ex-con sets off on a roller coaster ride of vengeance to unmask the mobsters who framed him for an armored truck heist.

sources.title: Kansas City Confidential (1952) Crime Drama | Film-Noir | Full Movie
sources.description:
THE CRIME THAT SHOCKED THE NATION!
An ex-con trying to go straight is framed for a million dollar armored car robbery and must go to Mexico in order to unmask the real culprits. 

Colorized version: https://youtu.be/oSgrXAes_MI
Director: Phil Karlson 
Writers: George Bruce, Harry Essex

metadata.Plot: A down-on-his-luck ex-G.I. finds himself a suspect in an armored car robbery. When he's finally released after the real robbery vehicle is found, after having been worked-over by the police, he sets out to discover who set him up, and why. The trail leads him into Mexico and a web of hired thugs and a corrupt cop.
metadata.Writer: George Bruce, Harry Essex, Harold Greene
metadata.Actors: John Payne, Coleen Gray, Preston Foster
